## Slide 5: WHY NOW
### Dental insurers must automate back-end tasks to improve margins due to recent regulatory pressures & market dynamics

**REGULATORY & MARKET PRESSURES ARE FORCING AUTOMATION**
- **Impending mandated dental loss ratios**
  As of 2025 in Mass, >83% of premium must go to care (vs.70% typically). Other states are expected to emulate as happened with medical. This would require payers to cut admin expenses to maintain margins while continuing to offer competitive premiums and benefits offerings
- **Competitive dental plans required to win market share**
  88% of Americans have dental insurance and >90% of MA plans (50M members) offer a dental benefit. Insurers (e.g., CVS/Aetna, Humana) are forced to reduce admin costs for dental benefits to continue to offer competitive benefits to attract members who see dental as a differentiator (#2 benefit after medical)
- **Value-based care requires more benefits integration**
  Medical-dental integration is starting to show effective outcomes (Kaiser, BCBS), driving adoption of more complex plan design and increased spend on manual admin resources

**BUT CARRIERS/DSOS STRUGGLE TO BUILD OR BUY AI SOLUTIONS**
- **Carriers / DSOs are actively looking for AI solutions**
  Insurers and providers have historically leveraged AI/ML for image analysis (~20% of claims require image analysis) but now want to leverage advances in LLMs to impact the other 80% of claims/interactions
- **Build: customers don't have human capital to build internally**
  Carriers/DSOs fundamentally cannot build product internally because they are unable to attract engineering talent required to implement novel technology solutions, especially AI. <1% of dental insurance organizations have built internal team for AI initiatives
- **Buy: existing vendors lack dental AND AI expertise**
  Existing dental specific platforms are antiquated, cumbersome and costly, (>$100M over 5 years per payer), while more general insuretech platforms aren't purpose built for dental - resulting in lower accuracy/automation for dental workflows

## Slide 14: ...that allows us multiple GTM strategies and ways of winning

This slide illustrates the modularity of the 32Health platform enabling a "Land and Expand" Go-To-Market (GTM) strategy.

**LAND:** The initial entry point into a client organization can be with a specific module, such as "Admin & adjudication" or "In-take automation" or "Credentialing". This corresponds to the highlighted blue box on the left, demonstrating that 32Health can enter a client with one of these core offerings.

**EXPAND:** Once a client has adopted one module, the platform allows for expansion into other areas, represented by the larger highlighted blue box that encompasses more modules like "Network management", "Contact center", "Billing & payments", and "Broker management". This shows the potential to cross-sell and up-sell additional functionalities, growing the relationship and value provided to the client.

The right panel shows a similar "Service Coverage" interface as on Slide 13, reinforcing that the platform provides granular configuration of plans and services, which supports the modular GTM approach. The ability to configure various plan details (Diagnostic, Preventive, Restorative, etc.) for specific codes (like D0120) and apply limitations suggests flexibility for tailored client solutions.

## Slide 14: ...that allows us multiple GTM strategies and ways of winning

This slide illustrates 32HEALTH's modular approach, enabling a "Land and Expand" Go-To-Market strategy. The left side presents the core modular components of the platform, categorized into PROVIDERS, CLAIMS, and FINANCE AND OPS, with sub-modules like Network management, Credentialing, Admin & adjudication, In-take automation, Contact center, Billing & payments, and Broker management.

The "LAND" strategy is depicted by highlighting key individual modules such as "Admin & adjudication" and "In-take automation" or "Credentialing" as initial entry points into client accounts. This means 32HEALTH can offer specific high-impact solutions first.

The "EXPAND" strategy, shown by a broader highlight encompassing more modules, illustrates the capability to cross-sell and up-sell additional platform functionalities once a client has adopted an initial module. This allows for growing engagement and recurring revenue by addressing more administrative needs within the client organization.

The right side of the slide shows a similar "Service Coverage" interface as on Slide 13 (e.g., D0120 Periodic Oral Evaluation, and other service categories like Diagnostic, Preventive, Restorative etc.). This visual reinforces the platform's configurability, which supports the flexible GTM strategies by allowing tailored solutions for different client needs and market segments.

**Client Product Adoption Details (Clients 1-39):**
- **AI Provider Network:** All clients from 1 to 39 are shown as either contracted (green) or projected (pink) in 2024 and 2025. Many clients start with this product.
- **AI Claims Admin System:** Clients 1-6 are contracted in 2024, with some projected for 2025. Many clients are shown as potential for expansion (light blue) in 2025.
- **AI Claims Intake Automation:** Some clients (e.g., 2, 7, 10, 14, 18, 22, 26, 30, 34, 38) are projected (pink) for 2024 and become potential for expansion (light blue) for Payers in 2025.
- **AI Contact Center:** Some clients (e.g., 4, 11, 15, 19, 23, 27, 31, 35, 39) are shown as contracted (green) or projected (pink) in 2024 and become potential for expansion (light blue) for Payers in 2025.

With $39M ARR in our sights for 2024 and 2025, we also have $260M potential ARR in our pipeline for 2026 and beyond.

- Contracted ARR (Green)
- Projected contracted ARR (Pink)
- Potential for expansion (Light Blue)
